## Correlation & NHST

> We will collect n = 10 observations

- Set alpha: for which $t$'s do we reject $H_0$?
  - P($t$ | $H_0: r = 0$)?
  - P($t$ | $H_1: r = 0.3$)?
  
```{r, echo=TRUE}
n <- 10
correlation <- 0.3
t.r <- ( correlation*sqrt(n-2) ) / sqrt(1-correlation^2)
t.r
```

---

## Confidence Intervals

- Based on the sampling distribution, centered on the observed statistic

```{r, echo=FALSE}
ll <- -1.96
uu <- 1.96
n <- 10
ss <- 1
mm <- 0
curve(dnorm(x, mm, ss), from = -3, to = 3, axes = FALSE, xlab = "t-statistics", ylab = "",
      main = "t Distribution (df = 9)", cex.lab = 1.5)
axis(1, at = c(-3,0, 3), labels = c(NA, expression("observed t"), NA))
sq <- seq(ll, uu, length.out = 1e3)
polygon(c(ll, sq, uu, sq), c(0, dnorm(sq, 0, 1), 0, rep(0, 1e3)), col = "lightgreen")
sq <- seq(-3, ll, length.out = 1e3)
polygon(c(-3, sq, ll, sq), c(0, dnorm(sq, 0, 1), 0, rep(0, 1e3)), col = "red")
sq <- seq(uu, 3, length.out = 1e3)
polygon(c(uu, sq, 3, sq), c(0, dnorm(sq, 0, 1), 0, rep(0, 1e3)), col = "red")
text(0, y = 0.2, "95%", cex = 2)
text(-2.3, y = 0.2, "2.5%", cex = 1.5)
text(2.3, y = 0.2, "2.5%", cex = 1.5)
arrows(-2.3, 0.01, -2.3, 0.15, lwd = 4)
arrows(2.3, 0.01, 2.3, 0.15, lwd = 4)
arrows(-1.96, 0.02, 0, 0.02, lwd = 2, lty = 1, code = 3, length = 0.1)
text(-1, 0.06, "Margin of error", cex = 1.1)
text(-1, 0.035, expression(SE ~ "x" ~ t[0.025]), cex = 1.1)
sq <- seq(-3, ll, length.out = 1e3)
polygon(c(-3, sq, ll, sq), c(0, dnorm(sq, 0, 1), 0, rep(0, 1e3)), col = "red")
sq <- seq(uu, 3, length.out = 1e3)
polygon(c(uu, sq, 3, sq), c(0, dnorm(sq, 0, 1), 0, rep(0, 1e3)), col = "red")
text(0, y = 0.2, "95%", cex = 2)
text(-2.3, y = 0.2, "2.5%", cex = 1.5)
text(2.3, y = 0.2, "2.5%", cex = 1.5)
```

### Confidence Intervals {.smaller}

::: {.columns}

::: {.column}

* On repeated sampling, $(100 - \alpha)%$ of the intervals contain population/true value
* If you conclude the present interval contains true value, you have $\alpha$% chance of being wrong (Misconception Mutt 2.1)
